clusters.title: Tradies find infant's body inside stormwater drain
clusters.neutral_headline: Infant's Body Found in Perth Stormwater Drain, Police Investigate
bullet_summary: The body of an infant has been found in a stormwater drain in Alexander Heights, in Perth's north
Police said multiple resources were deployed to the suburb of Alexander Heights after they received reports about 1pm on Monday
Police are investigating after an infant was found dead in a stormwater drain in a street in Perth's north

items.title: Tradies find infant's body inside stormwater drain
items.standfirst: Police have issued an emergency alert to all Perth maternity hospitals with concerns for the welfare of the mother.
items.content: T he body of an infant has been found in a stormwater drain in Perth's north, triggering a city-wide alert to maternity hospitals.Emergency services responded to reports a child had been discovered inside the drain in Alexander Heights about 1pm (3pm AEDT) today.Multiple resources attended the scene on La Salle Road, which was closed to the public.READ MORE: Surfer's narrow escape from 'great white' shark at NSW beach READ MORE: Crime group 'links' in spotlight after deadly Sydney pub shootingTradespeople working on the storm drain sounded the alarm after making the shocking discovery. A number of ambulance crews were called but stood down soon after when they realised there was nothing they could do to save the infant.This evening, police issued an emergency alert to all Perth maternity hospitals with concerns for the welfare of the mother.Detectives this afternoon spent a long time talking to all the neighbours on the street, looking for CCTV and asking if they'd noticed anything suspicious in the past 48 hours.They were expected to remain on the scene for some time. The age and gender of the child have not been confirmed. An investigation into the discovery of the child's body is ongoing.Anyone with information is urged to contact police immediately on 131 444.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Bulldog Jamarra Ugle-Hagan at the scene of nightclub shooting
clusters.neutral_headline: Bulldogs Player Ugle-Hagan Present at Nightclub Shooting Scene

items.title: Bulldog Jamarra Ugle-Hagan at the scene of nightclub shooting
items.standfirst: Western Bulldogs star Jamarra Ugle-Hagan was at the scene of a shooting outside of the Love Machine nightclub in the early hours of Sunday morning.
items.content: Western Bulldogs star Jamarra Ugle-Hagan was at the scene of a shooting outside of the Love Machine nightclub in the early hours of Sunday morning.

items.title: Western Bulldogs player Jamarra Ugle-Hagan caught up in nightclub shooting
items.standfirst: 9News understands Ugle-Hagan's friend became involved in a verbal altercation with another group before a fight broke out and a gun was fired about 2.25am on Sunday.
items.content: A FL star Jamarra Ugle-Hagan has been caught up in a non-fatal shooting outside a notorious Melbourne nightclub.The troubled Western Bulldogs forward was outside Love Machine on Chapel Street with a friend when the incident took place in the early hours of yesterday morning.9News Chief Football Reporter Tom Morris revealed Ugle-Hagan's friend became involved in a verbal altercation with another group before a fight broke out and a gun was fired about 2.25am.READ MORE: Surfer's narrow escape from 'great white' shark at NSW beachIt is believed Ugle-Hagan, who has not played any football this year due to mental health concerns, wasn't physically involved in the scuffle and that he walked back into the venue following the shooting incident.Victoria Police told 9News police are now investigating whether Ugle-Hagan had any involvement in the incident.No arrests have been made in connection to the shooting.The AFL and the Western Bulldogs declined to comment, telling 9News the latest incident is a police matter. It follows a separate incident last month after a car belonging to Ugle-Hagan was involved in a violent crime spree in Melbourne's south-east.9News revealed the white Jeep Cherokee was driven to several service stations, where a group of masked thieves allegedly carried out armed robberies.It's alleged the group first targeted a milk bar in Keysborough about 7.30pm, before travelling to a service station on Warrigal Road in Cheltenham about an hour later.READ MORE: Crime group 'links' in spotlight after deadly Sydney pub shootingREAD MORE: Qantas fined $90 million for illegally sacking staffThe Western Bulldogs said the club was aware of the incidents and were satisfied Ugle-Hagan was not involved.9News also exclusively revealed the same vehicle had been involved in a drive-by shooting in June.Three shots were fired at 71-year-old Doug Lee at his Glen Iris home.Ugle-Hagan was questioned by police and has been cleared of any wrongdoing.In a podcast, the 23-year-old said he'd given his car to a mate because he didn't trust himself driving.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.ai_summary:
• Western Bulldogs player Jamarra Ugle-Hagan was at a nightclub shooting.
• The shooting occurred outside the Love Machine nightclub.
• A friend of Ugle-Hagan was involved in a verbal altercation.
• A fight broke out before a gun was fired around 2:25 AM Sunday.
• The incident is under investigation by authorities.

clusters.title: 'Insane': Surfer's miracle escape from huge shark at NSW beach
clusters.neutral_headline: Surfer Has Narrow Escape from Shark Attack in New South Wales

items.title: 'Insane': Surfer's miracle escape from huge shark at NSW beach
items.standfirst: A surfer has had a narrow escape from a shark at a beach in northern NSW where a teenager was bitten just months ago.
items.content: A surfer has had a narrow escape from a shark at a beach in northern NSW where a teenager was bitten just months ago.Footage caught on Coast Cam at Cabarita Beach at 7.26am today shows surfer Brad Ross in the water alongside a dark shape, before splashing.The attack lasted only seconds and surfers around Ross were not immediately aware of what was unfolding.READ MORE: Major manhunt after deadly double shooting outside Sydney pubRoss was uninjured but a massive bite was taken from his board. Witness Kane Douglas described seeing an " explosion of water and foam"."One part of the board went that way, his board was still attached to him," Douglas said."The first thing I checked for when he started saying 'shark' was blood in the water." Grace Shaw told 9News she caught a wave moments before the attack. "We both looked at the wave and I got it, and it was amazing and then I looked back to paddle out and his board's in pieces and his mate's like, 'Mate are you okay?' and he's like, 'I don't know what happened, it just blew up'," Shaw said."I was just like, 'I'm okay, he's okay, if I'm gonna die, I'm gonna die'."Moments later a great white shark, approximately five metres long, was spotted on drone footage.Within hours, a nearby drum-line snagged a shark fitting that description but it broke free before it was able to be tagged.Shark expert Dr Daryl McPhee from Bond University said sharks were expected in the area at this time of year."We expect white sharks in that northern New South Wales area at this time of year following the bait fish and also following the whale migration," he said.READ MORE: Extraordinary move ahead of Zelenskyy, Trump meetingSurfing great Kelly Slater expressed his disbelief about the lucky escape."How does it bite that much and miss the guy? Insane!" he wrote in an Instagram comment.Cabarita Beach is south of Kingscliff, just south of the NSW-Queensland border. The beach was closed by the local Tweed Shire Council today. Mayor Chris Cherry said surfers seen in the water later that day were taking an "unnecessary risk". In June, a 16-year-old boy was hospitalised after an encounter with a shark at the same beach.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
